title: Uber Eats sets sights on grocery delivery with Costcutter tie-up
text:
More shoppers will be able to buy staples such as milk, butter and bread from hundreds of local shops as Uber Eats, the loss-making takeaway app, makes its first foray into the competitive grocery arena.

The tech company has struck a deal with Costcutter, the convenience store chain, to allow more than 1,700 shops to sell everyday items via the app, The Telegraph can reveal.

Toussaint Wattinne, general manager of Uber Eats in the UK, said: “Grocery is a massive opportunity and it’s one that complements well the offering that we have today. Our ambition is to offer a wide range of food choices in a convenient and fast way.”

Uber Eats’ tie-up with Costcutter is the latest in a flurry of similar...
description: More shoppers will be able to buy staples such as milk, butter and bread from hundreds of local shops as Uber Eats, the loss-making takeaway app, makes its first foray into the competitive grocery arena.
